stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses almost the entire session on a new "space plantation" sub-area inside the Space/Cosmic Colony world, experimenting with platform layout, visual style and performance on real N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: The new section is built around bumper springs that propel the player through rows of crops; half of the plantation still needs to be mapped out.
development_findings.quote: The idea with this area here, you use these bumpers to get around the plantation. I still need to make half the plantation.

development_findings.summary: Kaze adds glowing outlines to all platforms to solve edge-visibility problems against the blue galaxy backdrop.
development_findings.quote: I'm going to have glowing outlines on all the platforms in the end.

development_findings.summary: Springs were rethemed from a casino look to metallic, with reflective materials and a less rainbow colour scroll to fit the industrial space-farm aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: It's no longer a casino, it's something else now… maybe the spring itself can be more metallic.

development_findings.summary: A water-storage tank is prototyped; Kaze decides on a still-water shader generated at run-time and darker edges to imply volume.
development_findings.quote: I think this should be absolutely still water with no bubbles whatsoever… we’ll probably make a CPU-generated texture here.

development_findings.summary: Speed-run routes are consciously built in: players can long-jump or BLJ across large gaps, and new diagonal wall-jump sections were added for skilled movement.
development_findings.quote: That's absolutely the speedrun strategy… you can definitely PLJ over there and then bump into this and get up here.

development_findings.summary: A crash occurs when performing BLJs; Kaze identifies an infinite loop in his BLJ code and flags it for a fix.
development_findings.quote: Sometimes people say that PLJ is gone in this game… Maybe it is gone. My game crashed.

development_findings.summary: Performance test on real hardware shows 43 FPS in plant-heavy areas; render-distance tweaks and plant count will be optimised.
development_findings.quote: Well, I just click this button… now the game is uploaded to my N64 – 43 FPS. It doesn't like all these plants.

development_findings.summary: Skybox system uses a cube that follows the camera at adjustable percentages, saving memory versus traditional backgrounds.
development_findings.quote: For the space background, I have it set to 100 %, that way it feels like it's infinitely far away.

development_findings.summary: Post-game concepts include Luigi as a playable character and global difficulty modifiers (e.g., faster enemies).
development_findings.quote: Maybe I would do something like give people more freedom… you can now play as Luigi.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to open-source the project; leaks worry him only because players would experience an unfinished build.
development_findings.quote: I'm planning to open source this game anyway, so there's little point in leaking it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy is that a ROM-hack should stand on its own as a complete game, not merely as ‘content for people who already love Mario 64’.
context_findings.quote: I want to make sure that this ROM hack is also playable as a normal game without the context of Mario 64.

context_findings.summary: He dislikes over-long in-game text and invisible walls, preferring clarity through level design.
context_findings.quote: Everyone loves reading text in the game for no reason – that is good game design (sarcastic).

context_findings.summary: Streaming is draining for him; he considers a 30-day, 12-hour-per-day marathon funded by donations, explicitly for personal income rather than charity.
context_findings.quote: I'm not doing 30 days of working 15 hours a day for charity. That would be fun – for my bank account.

context_findings.summary: Personal tastes: lifelong resentment of Mario Tennis, current interest in ‘The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya’, scepticism about AI panic, and belief that ‘life is easy’ unless people complicate it.

biobak.summary: Most temporary textures and decorations in the prototype will later be reworked by Biobak.
biobak.quote: Keep in mind when I make these, that most of this is going to be reworked by Biobak anyway.

key_stories.title: BLJ Crash Mystery
key_stories.summary: While demonstrating a speed-run shortcut, Kaze’s build crashes whenever a backwards long jump is executed.
key_stories.challenge: Retain BLJ tech without destabilising the engine.
key_stories.process: Reproduced the crash live, confirming it stems from new BLJ code that can enter an infinite loop.
key_stories.outcome: Flagged for investigation; confident it can be patched quickly.
key_stories.key_quote: It seems right now there's something in the BLJ that unintentionally crashes… I guess I have to explicitly support it somehow.

key_stories.title: Re-theming the Springs
key_stories.summary: Bumper springs originally had a casino motif that clashed with the space-farm setting.
key_stories.process: Re-textured springs with metallic look, toned-down rainbow base, added reflective shader.
key_stories.outcome: Assets now match overall palette; performance acceptable on hardware.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe the spring itself can be more metallic… the color scroll at the bottom has to change to be less rainbow.

key_stories.title: Visibility Fix via Glowing Outlines
key_stories.summary: Players struggled to read platform edges against the galaxy backdrop.
key_stories.challenge: Poor depth perception and missed jumps.
key_stories.process: Added emissive borders around every platform, tested in emulator and on console.
key_stories.outcome: Edges now clearly readable; style ties entire level together.
key_stories.key_quote: The glowing rim really works well to outline the platforms.

key_stories.title: Water Tank Material Mishap
key_stories.summary: While prototyping a translucent water tank, Kaze accidentally overwrote the core material.
key_stories.process: Traced missing shine to wrong material slot, restored original settings, then designed new still-water shader concept.
key_stories.outcome: Material fixed; new plan for CPU-generated texture for subtle movement.
key_stories.key_quote: Something bad happened… I made the wrong material. Did I completely destroy the material?
